category_questions.question:
What is the relationship between
A: 'Cattle', and
B: 'Caribou' ?
Tag a node at the deepest level of the hierarchy.
Find and tag three (3) female film actors whose first name begins with 'M'.

What is the relationship between
A: 'Ordinal', and
B: 'Featherweight' ?
Find and tag all the moons of Uranus.

Navigate to the node 'Vietnam_War' and tag it.
Categories > Events > Historical > Wars > Global_Wars > The_Cold_War > Vietnam_War.
Tag a leaf-node (with no children) at Level 8 of the hierarchy, belonging to the category 'Organisations'.

'Royalty' and 'Deities' are sub-categories of 'Individuals'.
Tag the largest of these two nodes.
How many sub-categories of 'People' are there?
How many sub-categories of 'Vehicles' are there?
Tag the node which is the common ancestor of both 'Telephone' and 'Knives'
How many sub-categories are at Level 3 of the hierarchy?
Of the sub-categories at Level 3 of the hierarchy, which one is the smallest? Tag the node.
How many types of 'cars' manufactured by 'Mazda'' are shown in the visualisation?

Navigate to the node 'Calligraphy' and tag it.
Categories > Knowledge > Humanities > .... > Calligraphy.
According to the hierarchy, what type of vegetable is Cress? (tag it)

Does the hierarchy show more categories of Chinese or American Soups?
Tag the node with the largest value.
Return to the previously visited node 'Calligraphy' and tag it.

Does the hierarchy show more categories of 'Apollo Space Flights' or 'American Soups'?
Tag the node with the largest value.
Tag the node which is the common ancestor of both 'Hue' and 'Velocity'

What is the relationship between
A: 'Shredder', and
B: 'Cutting' ?
Return to the previously visited node 'Calligraphy' and tag it.

IciclePlot.question:
Icicle Plots - Training


This study explores how to effectively visualise Quantitative Hierarchical Data.

Hierarchical data is found in many applications including file systems, digital repositories, CPU stack traces, catalogues, software libraries, organisation charts, and logistics.

Examples of hierarchical data visualisations are shown below:

Features:
  • Both node-link and Icicle Plot diagrams show the hierarchical relationship between nodes.
  • In an icicle plot, child nodes are positioned directly underneath their parent.
  • The value of each node is the sum of the value of it's child nodes.
  • In the icicle plot,the value of each node is proportional to the width of the node.
In the above diagrams, some examples of the relationships are:

  • A is the root node, and is an ancestor of all nodes in the hierarchy.
  • A is the parent of B & C. It has a value of 100, which is a sum of the values of it's child nodes.
  • B has three children: D, E & F.
  • D, E & F are siblings, and are descendants of A.
  • D, E & F are leaf nodes (have no children).

Continue through this training by pressing the Next button.

Or, select 'Skip' to jump to information about naivgating the visualisation.
IciclePlot.title: Visualising Quantitative Hierarchical Data

Treemap.question:
Treemaps - Training


This study explores how to effectively visualise Quantitative Hierarchical Data.

Hierarchical data is found in many applications including file systems, digital repositories, CPU stack traces, catalogues, software libraries, organisation charts, and logistics.

Examples of hierarchical data visualisations are shown below:

Features:
  • Both node-link and Treemap diagrams show the hierarchical relationship between nodes.
  • In a Treemap plot, child nodes are positioned within the area of their r parent - i.e. the children are sub-divisions of the parent.
  • The value of each node is the sum of the value of it's child nodes.
  • In the Treemap diagram,the value of each node is proportional to the area of the node.
In the above diagrams, some examples of the relationships are:

  • A is the root node, and is an ancestor of all nodes in the hierarchy.
  • A is the parent of B & C. It has a value of 100, which is a sum of the values of it's child nodes.
  • B has three children: D, E & F.
  • D, E & F are siblings, and are descendants of A.
  • D, E & F are leaf nodes (have no children).

Continue through this training by pressing the Next button.
Treemap.title: Visualising Quantitative Hierarchical Data

Sundown.question:
Sundown Chart - Training


This study explores how to effectively visualise Quantitative Hierarchical Data.

Hierarchical data is found in many applications including file systems, digital repositories, CPU stack traces, catalogues, software libraries, organisation charts, and logistics.

Examples of hierarchical data visualisations are shown below:

Features:
  • Both node-link and Sundown Chart diagrams show the hierarchical relationship between nodes.
  • In a Sundown chart, child nodes are positioned radially adjacent to their parent.
  • The value of each node is the sum of the value of it's child nodes.
  • In the Sundown chart, the value of each node is proportional to the angle of the nodes arc.
In the above diagrams, some examples of the relationships are:

  • A is the root node, and is an ancestor of all nodes in the hierarchy.
  • A is the parent of B & C. It has a value of 100, which is a sum of the values of it's child nodes.
  • B has three children: D, E & F.
  • D, E & F are siblings, and are descendants of A.
  • D, E & F are leaf nodes (have no children).

Continue through this training by pressing the Next button.
Sundown.title: Visualising Quantitative Hierarchical Data

training.question:
xvisx - Training


The visualisation you will be using in this evaluation is based on Categories, and contains over 7500 nodes.

The visualisation contains context (top) and detail (main) views.
  • The context view is a compact view of the entire hierarchy.
  • The detail view, can be zoomed to focus on specific parts of the hierarchy.
training.title: General Navigation

training.question:
To adjust the text size, use the zoom on your browser:
  • Ctrl and + (Windows, Linux, and Chrome OS)
  • ⌘ and + (Mac).
training.title: General Navigation - Setup

IciclePlot.question:
Hovering the mouse over a node in the visualisation will show a 'tooltip' containing the name of the node. This is useful where the label is not visible, or too small to read.

Clicking on a node will expand the main view to focus on that node

PRACTICE TASKS:
IciclePlot.title: General Navigation

checks.check: Select any node by clicking on it.

checks.name: Categories
checks.check: Show the entire hierarchy by clicking on the root node 'Categories'.

Treemap.question:
The visualisation can be navigated by Clicking on a node to select a child node, or by clicking on the node's label

Return to a node's parent by using a right-click

'Breadcrumbs' are shown across the top of the main view, to show the path that has been followed when navigating to a node.

The breadcrumbs can be used to return to a node.

PRACTICE TASKS:
Treemap.title: General Navigation

checks.check: Select a node by clicking on it.
Click on a breadcrumb to zoom-out to that node.
Select a node by clicking on it, and then use right-click to return to it's parent.

IciclePlot.question:
The Detail View is the main part of the visualisation, and shows the hierarchy structure and the relative value of each node.

To focus on specific nodes, Zoom and Pan the visualisation using the mouse.

Nodes that have expanded to outside of the main area will be marked with arrows to indicate that only a 'partial' node is displayed.

PRACTICE TASKS:
IciclePlot.title: Detail View

checks.check: Zoom : by scrolling the mouse wheel.
Pan : by using 'click-and-drag' on the main part of the visualisation.

Treemap.question:
The Detail View is the main part of the visualisation, and shows the hierarchy structure and the relative value of each node.

Zoom and Pan can be used to move and zoom the visualisation using the mouse.

PRACTICE TASKS:
Treemap.title: Detail View

checks.check: Zoom : by scrolling the mouse wheel.
Pan : by using 'click-and-drag' on the main part of the visualisation.

training.question:
The context view is the 'compact view' located at the top of the visualisation.

The context view can be used to zoom and pan the 'detail view' - the main part of the visualisation.

To zoom: use the mouse to move the context-handles (red vertical lines).

To pan: click and drag the region between the context handles

PRACTICE TASKS:
training.title: Context View

checks.check: Context Zoom : by moving the 'handles'.
Context Pan : by dragging the region between the 'handles' the context view

training.question:
Nodes can be tagged and un-tagged using the spacebar.

The current node (as shown by the tooltip) directly under the mouse will be tagged.
The tagged node will be shown with a red outline, and as a red dot in the context view.

Clicking on the 'dot' will zoom to the tagged node.

PRACTICE TASKS:
training.title: Tagging Nodes

checks.check: Tag a node by hovering over it and pressing the spacebar.
Un-tag a node by pressing the spacebar again
Tag a node, then zoom to it by clicking on the 'red dot' in the context view

training.question:
There are four types of evaluation question.

  • Navigation
  • Size comparison
  • Relationships
  • Common Ancestor
To complete the evaluation questions, you will be prompted to 'tag' nodes (using the spacebar), or select from given options.

The selected node is shown in the 'Response' area.

PRACTICE TASKS:
training.title: Tagging Nodes

checks.check: Answer a question by tagging a node - see it in the response area.
Remove an answer by clicking the 'x' on a coloured bar in the response area.

training.question:
For some questions, helper nodes are provided, and shown as orange dots in the context view, and coloured bars in the question area.
The nodes are also outlined on the detail view.

The helper nodes can be used to help find nodes.

PRACTICE TASKS:
training.title: Helper Nodes

checks.check: Click on a helper node in the context view to zoom the main view to focus on the helper node.

training.question:
When answering the evaluation questions ... remember to:
  • Tag a node by hovering over it (check the tooltip label), and pressing the spacebar, or
  • If options are provided, pick an option.


Select the 'Next' button to try some practice questions, or select the 'x' button to exit training.
training.title: Practice Questions

training.question:
Navigation questions require you to navigate to a specific node, and then tag it by using a spacebar.

Tips:
- Follow the navigation path provided.
- If a label is too small, use the scroll wheel to zoom, or hover with the mouse.

PRACTICE TASKS:
training.title:
Practice Question:
Navigation 1

checks.name: Vietnam_War
checks.check:
Navigate to the node 'Vietnam_War' and tag it.

-> Categories
-> Events
-> Historical
-> Wars
-> Global_Wars
-> The_Cold_War
-> Vietnam_War

training.question:
Tips:
It's OK to skip a level or two!

PRACTICE TASKS:
training.title:
Practice Question:
Navigation 2

checks.name: F4_Phantom
checks.check:
Navigate to the node 'F4_Phantom' and tag it.

-> Things
-> Artificial
-> Tangible
-> Mechanical
->Machines
-> Vehicles
-> Aircraft
-> Jets
-> Military
-> American
-> Fighters
-> Carrier-Based
-> F4_Phantom

training.question:
Size comparison questions require you to determine which node is the largest. Two helper nodes will be provided.
Tips:
- The scale provided on the visualisation may be useful.
- Click on the helper nodes in the context view to help locate the nodes.

PRACTICE TASKS:
training.title:
Practice Question:
Size Comparison 1

checks.name: Sixth_Army
checks.check:
Compare the size of 'Sixth_Army' and 'Running_Backs'

Use the spacebar to tag the largest of these two nodes.

training.question:
More Tips:
- To see both nodes at once, use the mouse scroll-wheel to zoom in/out.

PRACTICE TASKS:
training.title:
Practice Question:
Size Comparison 2

checks.name: Severity
checks.check:
Compare the size of 'Severity' and 'Musical_Tempo'

Use the spacebar to tag the largest of these two nodes.

training.question:
Node Relationship questions require you to determine the relationship between two nodes.

PRACTICE TASKS:
training.title:
Practice Question:
Node Relationship 1

checks.check:
What is the closest relationship between
'Severity' and> 'Hurricanes'?

training.question:
Node Relationship questions require you to determine the relationship between two nodes.

PRACTICE TASKS:
training.title:
Practice Question:
Node Relationship 2

checks.check: What is the closest relationship between 'Public_Interest', and 'Sports'?

training.question:
Common Ancestor questions require you to determine the Lowest Common Ancestor shared by two nodes.
The answer is the lowest node in the hierarchy which is an ancestor of both nodes.

PRACTICE TASKS:
training.title:
Practice Question:
Common Ancestor 1

checks.check:
What is the Lowest Common Ancestor of the nodes
A: 'Loudness', and
B: 'Lieutenant_Corporal'?

training.question:
Common Ancestor questions require you to determine the Lowest Common Ancestor shared by two nodes.
The answer is the lowest node in the hierarchy which is an ancestor of both nodes.

PRACTICE TASKS:
training.title:
Practice Question:
Common Ancestor 2

checks.check:
What is the Lowest Common Ancestor of the nodes
A: 'Neurosrgeon', and
B: 'Mother'?

training.question:
Training Complete


The questions provided in the evaluations will be similar to these.

You are welcome to explore the hierarchy before proceeding with the formal valuation!

If you have any questions ... please ask!
training.title: Any Questions?

survey_questions.question: In what field is your degree?
How would you rate yourself in visualisations and design?

Based on your interactions with the ICICLE PLOT visualisation, to what extent do you agree with the statement:

'I never felt lost'

Based on your interactions with the ICICLE PLOT visualisation, to what extent do you agree with the statement:

'Transitions were smooth'

Based on your interactions with the ICICLE PLOT visualisation, to what extent do you agree with the statement:

'The context view was useful'

Based on your interactions with the ICICLE PLOT visualisation, to what extent do you agree with the statement:

'Navigation was assisted by node labels'
What did you like the most about the ICICLE PLOT visualisation?
What aspects of the ICICLE PLOT visualisation do you think could be improved?

Based on your interactions with the SUNDOWN visualisation, to what extent do you agree with the statement:

'I never felt lost'

Based on your interactions with the SUNDOWN visualisation, to what extent do you agree with the statement:

'Transitions were smooth'

Based on your interactions with the SUNDOWN visualisation, to what extent do you agree with the statement:

'The context view was useful'

Based on your interactions with the SUNDOWN visualisation, to what extent do you agree with the statement:

'Navigation was assisted by node labels'
What did you like the most about the SUNDOWN visualisation?
What aspects of the SUNDOWN visualisation do you think could be improved?

rating:
Not Applicable
No experience with visualisations and designs.

Beginner
Have experience learning visualisations and designs, capable of reading graphic charts, e.g. pie chart, line chart, scatter plot and etc.

Knowledgeable
Capable of understanding the pros and cons of different graphics and choosing the right graphics for given data

Skilled
Have related working experience for more than 1 year, or capable of Creating visualisations to explore and analyse given large data.

Expert
Have related working experience for more than 3 years, or have been involved in related industrial or government projects, or have academic publications in related fields.
